the government shuts down bambuser a

glands I'm a reporter at The New York
Times and I've been working on a story
my colleague John Markov on the shutdown
of the Internet in Egypt it happened
over a course of five days during the
height of the protests and what we're
finding is that this is the first time
we've seen a government throw what might
be called a nuclear switch shut down the
internet entirely because it was unhappy
with what the protesters were putting
out there and afraid of what the
consequences might be the internet is
famous for having lots of
interconnections so if you shut down one
part there's always a way to route
around it that's the way the internet
was designed but it turns out that when
it comes to individual countries it
doesn't quite work that way there were
very few ways in and out of especially
authoritarian regimes when it comes to
the internet because they designed it
that way so the government Internet
company the government networks called
telecom Egypt controls the portals to
the outside world there are lots of
commercial providers inside they've all
got to use telecom Egypt's portals so
what Egypt did what the Egyptian
government did is went to those
international portals just a few a
handful and it shut them down so the
question is does this capability exists
in other countries we don't know but we
see during the protests in Bahrain
and Iran especially activists are
telling us that by their measures the
internet is being severely slowed in
those countries so far not stopped the
concern is that given the role that
social media have played in organizing
the protests in these various countries
that governments may resort again to
this kill switch or find new ways to
restrict the flow of information on the
internet i'm robert mackey i write the
lead blog for the new york times website
one of the things that we've been seeing
as we followed protests across North
Africa and the Middle East in recent
weeks is the use of a new site to stream
live video clips from cell phones called
bambuser in unlike YouTube which is a
way of uploading recorded clips bambuser
actually lets people take out their
phones connect to the web and stream
live video of what's happening right at
that moment the clips are also archived
and recorded so you can see them on the
site later on the site was filtered were
blocked in Egypt during the protests
there and today what we've seen as
protests are going on for a second
straight day in Bahrain is that people's
channels within Bahrain are being
blocked on Tuesday there was a large
funeral procession for a protester was
killed on Monday and two different
bloggers used their accounts I'm
bambuser to post images about as it was
happening apparently this is something
that might have upset the authorities in
Bahrain because the bambuser accounts of
those users inside Bahrain are now
blocked one of the things that's
interesting about the bambuser footage
of the procession is that it gives you
an idea like any video would of how
large the procession was there seem to
be thousands of protesters but it also
is geo-located from the person's phone
so as they're streaming the video you
can see on a Google map posted right
next to the video that actually shows
you where someone is and exactly when
they've posted something is invaluable
to citizen journalism being used by the

it's always a bit of a challenge there
are times like this when it when you
just cannot go to Iran to report there
they won't give you visas and they ban

have to rely on a variety of sources
there's a group of sympathizers who put

on which is Monday's date on the iranian
